properties.description: This initiative includes policies that address the Dutch Baseline Informatiebeveiliging (BIO) controls specifically for the 'thema-uitwerking Clouddiensten' and include policies covered under the SOC2 and ISO 27001:2013 controls.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_B.01.3(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The requirements applicable to the CSC arising from laws and regulations have been identified, especially with regard to geographically distributed processing, storage and communications for which different legislation exists, such as measures arising from the GDPR.

policyDefinitionGroups.category: B.09 Privacy and protection of personal data
policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_B.09.1(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Availability, integrity and confidentiality measures have been taken for the storage, processing and transport of data

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_B.10.2(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The security feature provides proactive support for, cloud risk assessment activities; classifying information and systems; use of encryption; securing related projects; developing business continuity program and security audits.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_B.10.3(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The CSP has given the information security organization a formal position within the entire organization.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_B.10.4(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The CSP has described and assigned information security responsibilities for defining, coordinating and evaluating  to specific officers.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_C.04.3(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: If the probability of abuse and the expected damage are both high (NCSC classification vulnerability warnings), patches are installed as soon as possible, but no later than within a week. In the meantime, mitigating measures are taken on the basis of an explicit risk assessment.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_C.04.6(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Technical weaknesses can be remedied by performing patch management in a timely manner, which includes: identifying, registering and acquiring patches; the decision-making around the use of patches; testing patches; performing patches; registering implemented patches.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_C.04.7(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Evaluations of technical vulnerabilities are recorded and reported.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_C.04.8(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The evaluation reports contain suggestions for improvement and are communicated with managers/owners of ICT components in which vulnerabilities and weaknesses have been found.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_C.05.5(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Demonstrably, follow-up is given to improvement proposals from analysis reports.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.03(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The agreed continuity is guaranteed by sufficiently logical or physically multiple system functions.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.03.1(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The agreed continuity is guaranteed by sufficiently logical or physically multiple system functions.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.03.2(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The continuity requirements for cloud services agreed with the CSC organization are ensured by specific measures described in the system architecture.

policyDefinitionGroups.category: U.04 Data and Cloud Service Recovery
policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.04.1(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: In the event of calamities, the data and cloud services are restored within the agreed period and maximum data loss and made available to the CSC.

policyDefinitionGroups.category: U.04 Data and Cloud Service Recovery
policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.04.2(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The continuous process of recoverable protection of data is monitored.

policyDefinitionGroups.category: U.04 Data and Cloud Service Recovery
policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.04.3(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The adequate functioning of recovery functions is periodically tested by qualified personnel and the results are shared with the CSC.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.05.1(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Data transport is secured with cryptography to the latest state of the art (in accordance with the Forum for Standardization), whereby the key management is carried out by the CSC itself if possible.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.05.2(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Data stored in the cloud service shall be protected to the latest state of the art with encryption and with a key length sufficient at least for the purpose, whereby the key management is not purchased as a cloud service if possible and is carried out by the CSC itself.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.07.1(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Permanent isolation of data is realized within a multi-tenant architecture. Patches and adjustments of applications and infrastructure are realized in a controlled manner for all cloud services that the CSC purchases.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.07.3(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Isolation of CSC data is ensured by separating it at least logically from the data of other CSCs under all operating conditions.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.09.3(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The malware protection is carried out on various environments, such as on mail servers, (desktop) computers and when accessing the organization's network. The scan for malware includes: all files received over networks or through any form of storage medium, even before use; all attachments and downloads even before use; virtual machines; network traffic.

policyDefinitionGroups.category: U.10 Access to IT services and data
policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.10.2(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Under the responsibility of the CSP, administrators shall be granted access: to data with the least privilege principle; to data with the need-to-know principle; with multi-factor authentication; to data and application functions via technical measures.

policyDefinitionGroups.category: U.10 Access to IT services and data
policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.10.3(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Only users with authenticated equipment can access IT services and data.

policyDefinitionGroups.category: U.10 Access to IT services and data
policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.10.5(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Under the responsibility of the CSP, privileges (system authorisations) for users are granted through formal procedures.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.11.1(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The cryptography policy includes at least the following topics: when cryptography is used; who is responsible for the implementation of cryptology; who is responsible for key management; which standards serve as a basis for cryptography and the way in which the standards of the Standardisation Forum are applied; the way in which the level of protection is determined; in the case of communication between organizations, the policy is determined among themselves.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.11.2(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: In the case of PKIoverheid certificates: apply the PKIoverheid requirements with regard to key management. In other situations: use the ISO 11770 standard for managing cryptographic keys.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.11.3(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Sensitive data (on transport and at rest) is always encrypted, with private keys managed by the CSC. The use of a private key by the CSP is based on a controlled procedure and must be jointly agreed with the CSC organisation.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.12.1(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: In connection points with external or untrusted zones, measures have been taken to identify and respond to possible attacks that negatively affect the availability of information (e.g. Distributed Denial of Service attacks (DDos) attacks).

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.12.2(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: Physical and virtualized network components are designed and configured in such a way that network connections between trusted and untrusted networks are limited and monitored (monitored).

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.15.1(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The violation of the policy rules is recorded by the CSP and the CSC.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.15.3(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: The CSP maintains a list of all assets that are critical in terms of logging and monitoring and regularly reviews this list for correctness.

policyDefinitionGroups.name: NL_BIO_Cloud_Theme_U.17.1(2)
policyDefinitionGroups.description: CSC data on transport and at rest is encrypted.

metadata.description: The RegEx rule used to match allowed container image field in a Kubernetes cluster. For example, to allow any Azure Container Registry image by matching partial path: ^[^\/]+\.azurecr\.io\/.+$ and for multiple registries: ^([^\/]+\.azurecr\.io|registry\.io)\/.+$
The effect determines what happens when the policy rule is evaluated to match.

The 'SupplementalGroups' rule that containers are allowed to run with. MustRunAs requires at least one range to be specified. MayRunAs does not require that 'SupplementalGroups' be specified. RunAsAny allows any
Specify a supported Java version for App Service
The list of service ports allowed in a Kubernetes cluster. Array only accepts strings. Example: ["443", "80"]
List of API Management SKUs against which this policy will be evaluated.
The minimum value in the allowable host port range that pods can use in the host network namespace.
The list of SKUs that support software-based double encryption
Name of the resource group of NetworkWatcher, such as NetworkWatcherRG. This is the resource group where the Network Watchers are located.
The 'RunAsGroup' rule that containers are allowed to run with. MustRunAs requires at least one range to be specified. MayRunAs does not require that 'RunAsGroup' be specified. RunAsAny allows any

metadata.displayName: Double encryption should be enabled on Recovery Services vaults for Backup
metadata.description: Check if double encryption is enabled on Recovery Services vaults for Backup.  For more details refer to https://aka.ms/AB-InfraEncryption.

metadata.displayName: Scope Policy to Azure Monitor Agent-Supported Operating Systems
metadata.description: If set to true, the policy will apply only to virtual machines with supported operating systems. Otherwise, the policy will apply to all virtual machine resources in the assignment scope. For supported operating systems, see https://aka.ms/AMAOverview.
The minimum TLS protocol version that should be enabled. Windows machines with lower TLS versions will be marked as non-compliant.

List of Kubernetes namespaces to exclude from policy evaluation. System namespaces "kube-system", "gatekeeper-system" and "azure-arc" are always excluded by design. "azure-extensions-usage-system" is optional to remove.
The list of capabilities that are allowed to be added to a container. Provide empty list as input to block everything.
Array with allowed public IP addresses. An empty array is evaluated as to allow all IPs.
By selecting this option, you agree to be charged monthly per Arc connected machine.
The required resource logs retention (in days)

The source k8s object for constraint evaluation. 'Original' means only evaluate against the specific GroupVersionKind specified in the policy definition. 'Generated' means only evaluate against k8s objects generated by Gatekeeper ExpansionTemplates. 'All' means evaluate against both the original object and any generated ones.
Set this value to true if pod is allowed to use host network otherwise false.

metadata.displayName: Status if Windows Defender is not available on machine
metadata.description: Windows Defender Exploit Guard is only available starting with Windows 10/Windows Server with update 1709. Setting this value to 'Non-Compliant' shows machines with older versions on which Windows Defender Exploit Guard is not available (such as Windows Server 2012 R2) as non-compliant. Setting this value to 'Compliant' shows these machines as compliant.
The user ID ranges that are allowed for containers to use. Set 'max' as '-1' to skip max limit evaluation. Empty array blocks every defined value for 'MustRunAs'.
The 'FSGroup' rule that containers are allowed to run with. MustRunAs requires at least one range to be specified. MayRunAs does not require that 'FSGroup' be specified. RunAsAny allows any

The 'RunAsUser' rule that containers are allowed to run with. MustRunAs requires at least one range to be specified. MustRunAsNonRoot requires the pod be submitted with non-zero runAsUser or have USER directive defined (using a numeric UID) in the image. RunAsAny allows any runAsUser to be specified
The list of capabilities that must be dropped by a container.
The list of AppArmor profiles that containers are allowed to use. E.g. [ "runtime/default", "docker/default" ]. Provide empty list as input to block everything.
The list of locations that resource groups can be created in.

metadata.displayName: Optional: List of virtual machine images that have supported Linux OS to add to scope
metadata.description: Example value: '/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/YourResourceGroup/providers/Microsoft.Compute/images/ContosoStdImage'

The list of InitContainers and Containers to exclude from policy evaluation. The identifier is the image of container. Prefix-matching can be signified with `*`. For example: `myregistry.azurecr.io/istio:*`. It is recommended that users use the fully-qualified Docker image name (e.g. start with a domain name) in order to avoid unexpectedly exempting images from an untrusted repository.
Array with forbidden public IP addresses. An empty array is evaluated as there are no forbidden IP addresses.
The maximum memory bytes allowed for a container. E.g. 1Gi. For more information, please refer https://aka.ms/k8s-policy-pod-limits

metadata.displayName: Allowed file system group ID ranges
metadata.description: The file system group ranges that are allowed for pods to use. Set 'max' as '-1' to skip max limit evaluation. Empty array blocks every defined value for 'MustRunAs' and 'MayRunAs'.
The maximum value in the allowable host port range that pods can use in the host network namespace.
Specify a supported Python version for App Service
List of Kubernetes namespaces to only include in policy evaluation. An empty list means the policy is applied to all resources in all namespaces.

metadata.displayName: Would you like to restrict specific IP addresses?
metadata.description: Select (Yes) to allow or forbid a list of IP addresses. If (No), the list of IP addresses won't have any effect in the policy enforcement
Specify a supported PHP version for App Service
Label query to select Kubernetes resources for policy evaluation. An empty label selector matches all Kubernetes resources.

schema.description: A label selector is a label query over a set of resources. The result of matchLabels and matchExpressions are ANDed. An empty label selector matches all resources.

matchLabels.description: matchLabels is a map of {key,value} pairs.

matchExpressions.description: matchExpressions is a list of values, a key, and an operator.

key.description: key is the label key that the selector applies to.

operator.description: operator represents a key's relationship to a set of values.

values.description: values is an array of string values. If the operator is In or NotIn, the values array must be non-empty. If the operator is Exists or DoesNotExist, the values array must be empty.

metadata.description: The maximum CPU units allowed for a container. E.g. 200m. For more information, please refer https://aka.ms/k8s-policy-pod-limits
The host paths allowed for pod hostPath volumes to use. Provide an empty paths list to block all host paths.
The supplemental group ID ranges that are allowed for containers to use. Set 'max' as '-1' to skip max limit evaluation. Empty array blocks every defined value for 'MustRunAs' and 'MayRunAs'.
The list of excluded API kinds for customer-managed key, default is the list of API kinds that don't have data stored in Cognitive Services
The group ID ranges that are allowed for containers to use. Set 'max' as '-1' to skip max limit evaluation. Empty array blocks every defined value for 'MustRunAs' and 'MayRunAs'.
Whether or not to return warnings back to the user in the kubectl cli

metadata.displayName: Optional: List of virtual machine images that have supported Windows OS to add to scope
metadata.description: Example value: '/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/YourResourceGroup/providers/Microsoft.Compute/images/ContosoStdImage'

List of virtual machine images that have supported Linux OS to add to scope. Example values: '/subscriptions/<subscriptionId>/resourceGroups/YourResourceGroup/providers/Microsoft.Compute/images/ContosoStdImage'
The list of InitContainers and Containers to exclude from policy evaluation. The identify is the name of container. Use an empty list to apply this policy to all containers in all namespaces.

policyDefinitions.policyDefinitionReferenceId: Allowed locations for resource groups
Allowed locations
Only secure connections to your Azure Cache for Redis should be enabled
Secure transfer to storage accounts should be enabled
A maximum of 3 owners should be designated for your subscription
There should be more than one owner assigned to your subscription

A vulnerability assessment solution should be enabled on your virtual machines
Azure Defender for servers should be enabled
Vulnerability assessment should be enabled on your Synapse workspaces
Azure Defender for Key Vault should be enabled
Microsoft Defender for Containers should be enabled
Azure Defender for App Service should be enabled
Azure Defender for SQL servers on machines should be enabled
Azure Defender for Resource Manager should be enabled
Azure Defender for Azure SQL Database servers should be enabled
Function apps should use latest -HTTP Version-
Kubernetes Services should be upgraded to a non-vulnerable Kubernetes version
App Service apps that use Java should use a specified -Java version-
App Service apps that use Python should use a specified -Python version-
Function apps that use Python should use a specified -Python version-
App Service apps that use PHP should use a specified -PHP version-
App Service apps should use latest -HTTP Version-
Function apps that use Java should use a specified -Java version-
SQL servers on machines should have vulnerability findings resolved
Windows Defender Exploit Guard should be enabled on your machines
Azure Machine Learning compute instances should be recreated to get the latest software updates
Azure Policy Add-on for Kubernetes service (AKS) should be installed and enabled on your clusters
Kubernetes cluster containers should only use allowed images
Kubernetes cluster should not allow privileged containers
Kubernetes cluster services should listen only on allowed ports
Kubernetes cluster containers CPU and memory resource limits should not exceed the specified limits
Kubernetes cluster pods and containers should only run with approved user and group IDs
Kubernetes clusters should not allow container privilege escalation
Kubernetes cluster containers should not share host process ID or host IPC namespace
Kubernetes cluster containers should run with a read only root file system
Kubernetes cluster containers should only use allowed capabilities
Kubernetes cluster containers should only use allowed AppArmor profiles
Kubernetes cluster pods should only use approved host network and port range
Kubernetes cluster pod hostPath volumes should only use allowed host paths
Kubernetes clusters should not use the default namespace
Kubernetes clusters should disable automounting API credentials
Kubernetes clusters should not grant CAP_SYS_ADMIN security capabilities
Function apps should have remote debugging turned off
App Service apps should have remote debugging turned off
Function apps should not have CORS configured to allow every resource to access your apps
App Service apps should not have CORS configured to allow every resource to access your apps
Azure running container images should have vulnerabilities resolved (powered by Microsoft Defender Vulnerability Management)
Azure Kubernetes Service clusters should have Defender profile enabled
Subscriptions should have a contact email address for security issues
Email notification for high severity alerts should be enabled
Email notification to subscription owner for high severity alerts should be enabled
Geo-redundant backup should be enabled for Azure Database for MySQL
Geo-redundant backup should be enabled for Azure Database for PostgreSQL
Geo-redundant backup should be enabled for Azure Database for MariaDB
Audit virtual machines without disaster recovery configured
Azure Backup should be enabled for Virtual Machines
Key vaults should have deletion protection enabled
Key vaults should have soft delete enabled
Function apps should only be accessible over HTTPS
App Service apps should only be accessible over HTTPS
Azure Edge Hardware Center devices should have double encryption support enabled
Azure Batch pools should have disk encryption enabled
Azure HDInsight clusters should use encryption in transit to encrypt communication between Azure HDInsight cluster nodes
Kubernetes clusters should be accessible only over HTTPS
Function apps should require FTPS only
App Service apps should require FTPS only
Windows machines should be configured to use secure communication protocols
Enforce SSL connection should be enabled for PostgreSQL database servers
Azure SQL Database should be running TLS version 1.2 or newer
Azure Front Door Standard and Premium should be running minimum TLS version of 1.2
Enforce SSL connection should be enabled for MySQL database servers
App Service apps should use the latest TLS version
Function apps should use the latest TLS version
Transparent Data Encryption on SQL databases should be enabled
Azure HDInsight clusters should use encryption at host to encrypt data at rest
Infrastructure encryption should be enabled for Azure Database for PostgreSQL servers
Infrastructure encryption should be enabled for Azure Database for MySQL servers
vTPM should be enabled on supported virtual machines
Secure Boot should be enabled on supported Windows virtual machines
Guest Attestation extension should be installed on supported Linux virtual machines
Guest Attestation extension should be installed on supported Linux virtual machines scale sets
Guest Attestation extension should be installed on supported Windows virtual machines
Guest Attestation extension should be installed on supported Windows virtual machines scale sets
Virtual machines and virtual machine scale sets should have encryption at host enabled
Double encryption should be enabled on Azure Data Explorer
Azure Data Box jobs should enable double encryption for data at rest on the device
Azure Monitor Logs clusters should be created with infrastructure-encryption enabled (double encryption)
Storage accounts should have infrastructure encryption
Disk encryption should be enabled on Azure Data Explorer
Temp disks and cache for agent node pools in Azure Kubernetes Service clusters should be encrypted at host
Azure API for FHIR should use a customer-managed key to encrypt data at rest
SQL servers should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
Azure Container Instance container group should use customer-managed key for encryption
PostgreSQL servers should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
Azure Monitor Logs clusters should be encrypted with customer-managed key
Azure Cosmos DB accounts should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
Logic Apps Integration Service Environment should be encrypted with customer-managed keys
Service Bus Premium namespaces should use a customer-managed key for encryption
Azure Recovery Services vaults should use customer-managed keys for encrypting backup data
IoT Hub device provisioning service data should be encrypted using customer-managed keys (CMK)
Azure data factories should be encrypted with a customer-managed key
Bot Service should be encrypted with a customer-managed key
Azure Automation accounts should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
Container registries should be encrypted with a customer-managed key
Azure HDInsight clusters should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
Azure AI Services resources should encrypt data at rest with a customer-managed key (CMK)
Storage accounts should use customer-managed key for encryption
OS and data disks should be encrypted with a customer-managed key
Both operating systems and data disks in Azure Kubernetes Service clusters should be encrypted by customer-managed keys
Azure Data Explorer encryption at rest should use a customer-managed key
MySQL servers should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
Azure Data Box jobs should use a customer-managed key to encrypt the device unlock password
Azure Stream Analytics jobs should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data
HPC Cache accounts should use customer-managed key for encryption
Azure Batch account should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data
Event Hub namespaces should use a customer-managed key for encryption
SQL managed instances should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
Storage account encryption scopes should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
Azure Machine Learning workspaces should be encrypted with a customer-managed key
Managed disks should be double encrypted with both platform-managed and customer-managed keys
Azure Synapse workspaces should use customer-managed keys to encrypt data at rest
Saved-queries in Azure Monitor should be saved in customer storage account for logs encryption
Windows virtual machines should enable Azure Disk Encryption or EncryptionAtHost.

Azure Cosmos DB should disable public network access
Azure Machine Learning Computes should be in a virtual network
Azure Databricks Workspaces should disable public network access
Azure Databricks Clusters should disable public IP
Azure Databricks Workspaces should use private link
Azure Databricks Workspaces should be in a virtual network
Storage accounts should restrict network access
All network ports should be restricted on network security groups associated to your virtual machine
Azure Web Application Firewall should be enabled for Azure Front Door entry-points
Azure AI Services resources should restrict network access
Private endpoint should be enabled for PostgreSQL servers
Private endpoint should be enabled for MariaDB servers
Authorized IP ranges should be defined on Kubernetes Services
Public network access on Azure SQL Database should be disabled

Subnets should be associated with a Network Security Group

API Management services should use a virtual network

Internet-facing virtual machines should be protected with network security groups

Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) should be used on Kubernetes Services

Blocked accounts with read and write permissions on Azure resources should be removed

Service Fabric clusters should only use Azure Active Directory for client authentication
Azure AI Services resources should have key access disabled (disable local authentication)

Audit usage of custom RBAC roles
